'''''Lepiota castaneidisca''''' is a species of [[agaric]] fungus in the family [[Agaricaceae]]. Formally described in 1912, it was for a long time considered the same species as the similar ''[[Lepiota cristata]]'' until [[molecular phylogenetics|molecular]] analysis reported in 2001 demonstrated that it was genetically distinct. It is most common in coastal and northern [[California]], and has also been recorded in Mexico. A [[saprobic]] species, it is usually found under [[Sequoia sempervirens|redwood]] and [[Cupressus macrocarpa|Monterey cypress]]. Its [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] ([[mushroom]]s) have white [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] with an orange-red to orange-brown center that measure up to {{convert|3.2|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide. The cream-colored to light pink [[stipe (mycology)|stems]] are up to {{convert|6.5|cm|in|abbr=on}} long by {{convert|0.2|–|0.6|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick, and have a [[annulus (mycology)|ring]]. ''L. castaneidisca'' can be distinguished from other similar ''[[Lepiota]]'' species by differences in habitat, macroscopic, or microscopic characteristics.

==Systematics==

The species was first [[species description|described]] as new to science by mycologist [[William Alphonso Murrill]] in 1912. Murrill collected the [[type (biology)|type]] material growing near redwoods near [[Searsville Lake]], [[California]], in December 1911.<ref name="Murrill 1912"/> In 1914,<ref name="Murrill 1914"/> Murrill decided that the species was the same as ''[[Lepiota cristata]]'' (which he called ''Lepiota conspurcata'' (Willd.) Morgan); this opinion was later corroborated by Walter Sundberg in 1989 after he studied the type collection and concluded that the microscopic characteristics of both were the same.<ref name="Sundberg 1989"/> Using [[molecular phylogenetics|molecular]] analysis based on comparing [[DNA sequence]]s of the [[internal transcribed spacer]] region, mycologist Else Vellinga determined that despite the lack of distinguishing [[morphology (biology)|micro-morphological]] characteristics, the two species were distinct.<ref name="Vellinga 2001"/>

The [[specific name (botany)|epithet]] ''castaneidisca'' refers to the chestnut-colored center of the cap. ''Lepiota'' means "the scaly one".<ref name="Vellinga 2007"/>

==Description==
[[File:Lepiota castaneidisca younger.JPG|thumb|left|A young fruit body]]
[[File:Lepiota_castaneidisca_spores.JPG|thumb|Spores 1000x]]
The [[Basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] of ''Lepiota castaneidisca'' have white, bell-shaped to convex [[pileus (mycology)|cap]]s {{convert|0.8|to|3.2|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} in diameter, with an orange-reddish to pale orange-brown center. Mature specimens fade and lose the reddish shades. The cap surface develops small pale pink or cream patches (especially on the outermost zone) on a white background that has radially arranged [[wikt:fibril|fibrils]].<ref name="Vellinga 2001"/> The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are somewhat crowded to moderately distant,<ref name="Vellinga 2007"/> with typically 40–45 full length gills, and 1–5 tiers of interspersed lamellulae (short gills that do not extend fully from the cap margin to the stem). They are slightly [[ventricose]], measuring 2.5–5 mm wide, and have a white fringed or irregular edge.<ref name="Vellinga 2001"/> Whitish when young and cream-colored in age, they have a free gill attachment to the stem.  The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is {{convert|25|–|65|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} long by {{convert|2|–|6|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick, cylindrical, slightly widened at the base, hollow, and [[wikt:fibrillose|fibrillose]]. Its color is pinkish in the lower part, and it stains reddish where damaged, especially in older specimens.<ref name="Vellinga 2007"/> The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is whitish, sometimes with cream tones, or reddish-brown in mature specimens.<ref name="Vellinga 2001"/> There is a [[annulus (mycology)|ring]] that points upward in young specimens, but in maturity it degrades to remnants that are left behind on the stem. It has a sharp odor similar to [[rubber]] or [[cod liver oil]].<ref name="Vellinga 2007"/>  The mushroom is not known to be [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]], but consumption is not recommended due to the risk of possible confusion with ''[[Lepiota]]'' species that contain deadly [[amatoxin]]s.<ref name="MykoWeb"/>

The smooth, [[dextrinoid]] [[spore]]s are in side view triangular with a spurred base, in frontal view oblong, and typically measure 5–9 by 3–4 [[micrometre|μm]].<ref name="Vellinga 2001"/> [[Staining]] with Cresyl blue shows them to be somewhat [[Metachromasy|metachromatic]], and [[Cell nucleus|binucleate]].<ref name="Vellinga 2010"/> [[Cystidia]] on the gill edge (cheilocystidia) are club-shaped to cylindric or sometimes spheropedunculate (somewhat spherical with a stem), and have dimensions of 20–44 by 6.5–13.5 μm. [[Basidia]] are 18–30 by 5–8 [[micrometre|μm]], mostly four-spored, and are absent on the gill edge. Pleurocystidia (cystidia on the gill face) are absent. The [[cap cuticle]] is a hymeniderm (lengthened cells arranged side by side) with mostly colorless elements of different lengths, measuring 16–62 by 8–18 μm.<ref name="Vellinga 2007"/> The stipitipellis (outer covering of the stem) comprises a layer of colorless [[hypha]]e measuring about 2–3 μm wide. [[Clamp connection]]s are present in the hyphae of all parts of the fungus.<ref name="Vellinga 2001"/>

===Similar species===
[[File:Lepiota cristata 20070819w.jpg|thumb|right|''Lepiota cristata'' is a lookalike species.]]
''Lepiota castaneidisca'' closely resembles ''L. cristata'' (with which it has commonly been confused),<ref name="MykoWeb"/> but it has a more rounded cap, lacks an [[umbo (mycology)|umbo]], and is reddish- or pinkish-brown, rather than orange-brown.<ref name="Vellinga 2001"/> ''L. cristata'', which is widely distributed in the [[Northern Hemisphere]], prefers habitats where the natural vegetational cover has been disturbed by humans, or in the beds of rivers and creeks; in contrast, ''L. castaneidisca'' is found in natural, undisturbed habitats.<ref name="Vellinga 2007"/> Other similar species in similar habitats with which ''L. castaneidisca'' could be confused include ''[[Lepiota thiersii|L. thiersii]]'' and ''[[Lepiota neophana|L. neophana]]''; in contrast to ''L. castaneidisca'', both of the latter two species have ellipsoid spores.<ref name="Vellinga 2001"/> The fruit bodies of ''L. thiersii'' appear from November through April, and grow scattered or in groups under [[Cupressus macrocarpa|cypress]]. It usually lacks the reddish color in the center of the cap associated with ''L. castaneidisca'', and its spores are not as long, with dimensions of 4.7–6.3 by 3.1–3.9 μm. ''L. neophana'' is a rare species, but more widely distributed in the United States than ''L. castaneidisca'', as it has been reported from [[Ohio]] and [[Michigan]] in addition to California. It also fruits under cypress, usually between December and April. This mushroom is most readily distinguished from ''L. castaneidisca'' by the dark brown to blackish-brown color of the cap center.<ref name="Sundberg 1989"/>

==Habitat and distribution==

''Lepiota castaneidisca'' is a [[saprobic]] fungus.<ref name="Vellinga 2001"/> Fruit bodies appear in the late fall and winter (November to February), where they grow gregariously near cypress, [[Sequoia sempervirens|redwood]] or in mixed  [[Quercus agrifolia|coast live oak]] forests. The fungus is common in coastal and northern [[California]], and is often found in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]].<ref name="Vellinga 2007"/> The northern limit of its distribution is [[Washington (state)|Washington State]]<ref name="Vellinga 2010"/> and southern [[British Columbia]], and it has been recorded as far south as Mexico.<ref name="Aroche 1984"/>
